data.text: INDEX
Purpose

A pregnant or postnatal patient who is admitted for care or referred to another speciality from the Emergency Department or on a general ward should be seen by a midwife or obstetrician trained to recognise deviations from normal.

This initial triage assessment will take place at the Emergency Department and if appropriate the patient can be reviewed in the maternity unit following medical assessment and referral to the obstetric registrar/ consultant on call/midwife/ medical team.

To ensure that staff in all areas in the Trust can obtain the support of the maternity services and that midwifery staff in turn are aware of such individual cases and can act promptly and appropriately.
Equality Impact Assessment
Mid Essex Hospital Services NHS Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.
(Refer to Appendix C)
Background

The Confidential Enquiry into Maternal and Child Health ‘Why Mothers Die' 2003-2005 (2007) has made recommendations regarding the management of pregnant patients in emergency departments. The report recommends that there is an urgent need for the utilisation of a national obstetric early warning chart i.e. the PAR score (Patient at Risk Score) observation chart, which will help in the more timely recognition, treatment and referral of women who have, or are developing, a critical illness.
Furthermore, this report from the Confidential Enquiry into Maternal and Child Health (CEMACH), 2007 highlighted the following:

The management of patients who are acutely ill/collapsed for non-obstetric reasons should include early liaison with Ambulance Services, Emergency Department, Intensive Care Unit/Anaesthetic team Maternity Services
A lack of communication and teamwork between different professional groups

In 2008, the report commissioned by The King's Fund, ‘Safe Births: Everybody's Business', reviewed maternity services, entitled ‘Towards Better Births' identifying communication as a key area for improvement and development.
Policy Statement
This document covers all pregnant patients who are admitted to any other emergency service throughout the Trust.
The document excludes pregnant patients who attend routine outpatient's department services i.e. the outpatients' diabetic clinic.
The needs of those pregnant patients should be addressed as follows:
The care of pregnant patients with a medical condition requiring treatment and
hospitalisation should be discussed and planned in conjunction with the local obstetric team.
The system for ensuring that the on call consultant is aware of all pregnant women in hospital who have a non-obstetric problem is as follows:
All patients of childbearing age who present with unexplained abdominal pain should
have an ectopic pregnancy excluded as part of their investigations.
Local maternity services for the Trust provide care for patients and their babies from conception until 28 days following delivery for midwifery and obstetric care.
Points of Contact

Labour Ward for all pregnant patients who are more than16 weeks' gestation liaise with the Labour Ward Coordinator who can be contacted at any time for advice extension 3056 or 3057 (outside line 01245 362305 option 1, then 1).
Day Assessment Unit from 08.00 -19.30 extension 3355.
Antenatal clinic Monday to Friday 08.00-16.00 extension 3289 or 3664 (outside line 01245 362305 option 1, then 5).
Gosfield Ward for pregnant women 16 weeks or less any time extension 4921/ 4923 (outside line 01245 513037) and liaise with an obstetric registrar or consultant.
Management of Women Presenting in the Emergency Department
All female patients of childbearing age should be asked if they could be pregnant or have been pregnant in the last 28 days.

Pregnant patients who present at the Emergency Department with injuries of non-pregnancy related problem should be stabilised, careful assessment made of the pregnancy and the on call obstetric registrar alerted if required and appropriate.
All pregnant patients involved in ‘road traffic collisions' (RTC) however minor should
have an assessment of fetal wellbeing by a midwife or an obstetrician prior to discharge.

All rhesus negative women should have a blood sample taken for Kleihauer, full blood count (FBC) and group and save. The patient's blood group should be recorded on the telephone message record sheet once the obstetric/gynaecological teams are involved. (Refer to Appendix B)

If the condition of the patient is critical following any trauma, a clinical decision will be made by the Emergency Department staff on the most appropriate time to involve the labour ward coordinator and obstetric registrar.

Pregnant patients with raised blood pressure and symptomatic of pre-eclampsia, otherwise uncomplicated blood pressure may be reviewed by an obstetrician in the day assessment unit of the maternity department.
Role of the Ambulance Service
Prompt attention by the most appropriate professional team can lead to improved
outcomes. Ambulance personnel should be aware of the conditions in which direct referral to Labour Ward is most appropriate.
Direct Admissions to the Emergency Department via the Ambulance Service

When referring a pregnant patient to Labour Ward the Emergency Department staff should inform the Labour Ward Coordinator on extension 3056 or 3057 (outside line 01245 362305 option 1, then 1. (Refer to Appendix A)
Severe headache, nausea, vomiting or epigastric pain or generally unwell pregnant patients are reviewed as a clinical priority and assessed as an early referral in A&E.
At the point of assessment by a triage nurse or doctor in A&E, the staff member should contact the Labour Ward as stated in point 8.1.
Direct Emergency Department Referrals

Pregnant patients with ‘obvious injuries' or suspected internal injuries following RTC/Trauma. Following stabilisation of life threatening injuries, these patients should be transferred directly to Labour Ward. (Refer to Appendix A - Referral pathway flow chart).

Pregnant patients who have taken an overdose of any drugs or alcohol; and who have been subject to domestic abuse or where there are risks to the unborn and/or other siblings will be treated in the Emergency Department and the staff involved should contact the Labour Ward Coordinator with the patient's details.
(Refer to the guideline for ‘The management of domestic abuse in maternity patients'. Register number 06040)

Once the Emergency Department staff have informed the Labour Ward Coordinator, it is imperative that they ensure that all the specific details are recorded in the telephone message record folder. (Refer to Appendix B)
This record sheet should then be photocopied, the original being retained in the patient's hospital notes and finally, the photocopied sheet being placed in the labour ward manager's office.
Any other circumstances where the patient's life or wellbeing is obviously threatened.
These guidelines cannot anticipate all possible circumstances and exist only to provide general guidance on clinical management to clinicians.
All pregnant patients attending accident and emergency departments should be triaged initially on arrival and allocated a clinical priority.

The pregnancy presenting condition of Manchester Triage should be used when assessing pregnant patients to decide on clinical priority. If clinical priority is high; ( P1 or P2) then the patient should be immediately fast track to be seen by a senior Emergency Department doctor to ensure a senior obstetric doctor attends the Emergency Department for assessment.
In and Out of Hours GP
GP's who assess pregnant patients attending their GP surgery should qualify whether the patient's immediate condition is stable or unstable and take into consideration their geographical location.

If the decision to transfer the patient to Broomfield Hospital is indicated, the GP should contact the Labour Ward Coordinator and/or obstetric registrar with specific facts regarding the patient's diagnosis.

The telephone message book should be completed and a photocopy should be placed in the appropriately labelled filing tray for risk management or safeguarding, located in the Labour Ward Manager's office.

The telephone record sheet will form the basis of an ‘audit trail' for all women who attend the emergency services. Furthermore, improved communications between departments and Midwife-led Units will ensure that each patient has the necessary follow-on care. (Refer to Appendix B)

If the patient's condition is unstable, then the GP should make a referral to the obstetric team and book an emergency paramedic crew where the ambulance services and paramedic team can transfer the patient to Labour Ward or Gosfield Ward for immediate assessment and treatment if required.

Once the Emergency Department staff involved have assessed the patient, they should inform the Labour Ward Coordinator; who should then alert the obstetric or midwifery team to attend the Emergency Department immediately if the patient is not stable enough to transfer.
The Emergency Department Symphony system provides basic audit trail information for pregnant patients attending the Emergency Department.

Pregnant patients over 16 weeks who are bleeding per vaginum and/or whose membranes have ruptured; who have been assessed by their GP should be directly referred the Labour Ward for further treatment.
Staffing and Training
All midwifery and obstetric staff must attend yearly mandatory training which includes skills and drills training.
All midwifery and obstetric staff are to ensure that their knowledge and skills are up-to-date in order to complete their portfolio for appraisal.
There is a link on the intranet which includes management algorithms for all Emergency Department medical staff.
Professional Midwifery Advocates

Professional Midwifery Advocates provide a mechanism of support and guidance to women and midwives. Professional Midwifery Advocates are experienced practising midwives who have undertaken further education in order to supervise midwifery services and to advise and support midwives and women in their care choices. PMA's are available from 08:00 – 16:00 5 days a week rota via switchboard.
Infection Prevention
All staff should follow Trust guidelines on infection prevention by ensuring that they effectively ‘decontaminate their hands' before and after each procedure.
All staff should ensure that they follow Trust guidelines on infection prevention. All
invasive devices must be inserted and cared for using high impact intervention guidelines (refer to Saving Lives policy guideline, DoH, 2007) to reduce the risk of infection and
deliver safe care. This care should be recorded in the Saving Lives High Impact Intervention Monitoring Tool Paperwork (Medical Devices).

All staff should ensure that they follow Trust guidelines on infection control, using Aseptic Non-Touch Technique (ANTT) when carrying out procedures i.e. when obtaining blood samples, performing vagina examinations and conducting deliveries.
Audit and Monitoring

Audit of compliance with this guideline will be considered on an annual audit basis in accordance with the Clinical Audit Strategy and Policy (register number 08076), the Corporate Clinical Audit and Quality Improvement Project Plan and the Maternity annual audit work plan; to encompass national and local audit and clinical governance identifying key harm themes. The Women's and Children's Clinical Audit Group will identify a lead for the audit.
As a minimum the following specific requirements will be monitored:
Which women attending the emergency department should be seen by an experienced doctor from the obstetric/gynaecology team or a midwife;
Requirement that the care of pregnant women with non-obstetric problem(s) who require admission should be discussed and planned with the local obstetric team;
System for ensuring that the on-call obstetric consultant is aware of all sick pregnant women in the hospital who have a non-obstetric problem;
System for ensuring that the on call obstetric consultant is aware of all sick pregnant women in the hospital who have a problem related to their pregnancy;
Process for audit, multidisciplinary review of results and subsequent monitoring of action
plans.

A review of a suitable sample of health records of patients to include the minimum requirements as highlighted in point  will be audited. A minimum compliance 75% is required for each requirement. Where concerns are identified more frequent audit will be undertaken.

The findings of the audit will be reported to and approved by the Multi-disciplinary Risk Management Group (MRMG) and an action plan with named leads and timescales will be developed to address any identified deficiencies. Performance against the action plan will be monitored by this group at subsequent meetings.
The audit report will be reported to the monthly Directorate Governance Meeting (DGM) and significant concerns relating to compliance will be entered on the local Risk Assurance Framework.
Key findings and learning points from the audit will be submitted to the Clinical Governance Group within the integrated learning report.
Key findings and learning points will be disseminated to relevant staff.
Guideline Management

As an integral part of the knowledge, skills framework, staff are appraised annually to ensure competency in computer skills and the ability to access the current approved guidelines via the Trust's intranet site.

Quarterly memos are sent to line managers to disseminate to their staff the most currently approved guidelines available via the intranet and clinical guideline folders, located in each designated clinical area.
Communication

A quarterly ‘maternity newsletter' is issued and available to all staff including an update on the latest ‘guidelines' information such as a list of newly approved guidelines for staff to acknowledge and familiarise themselves with and practice accordingly.
Approved guidelines are published monthly in the Trust's Focus Magazine that is sent via email to all staff.
References

Lewis, G (ed) (2007) The Confidential Enquiry into Maternal and Child Health (CEMACH) Saving Mothers' Lives: reviewing maternal deaths to make motherhood safer – 2003-2005. The Seventh Report on Confidential Enquiries into Maternal Deaths in the United Kingdom. London: CEMACH
O'Neill, Onora (2008) Safe Births: Everybody's Business: an independent inquiry into the safety of maternity services in England. London: The King's Fund
www.kingsfund.org.uk
